awd_titl_txt: Controlled Environment Facilities for the Marine Biological Laboratory
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will provide funds for new controlled environment facilities at the Marine Biological Laboratory (MBL - https://www.mbl.edu). This will provide new capabilities to expand research on plant and soil processes, and microbial interactions with plants and animals.  Global change is a multi-factor phenomenon making the study of how organisms and ecosystems will respond to future changes all the more challenging. Facilities which can simultaneously control multiple relevant environmental drivers are needed to address relevant global change questions.  These facilities will be used to support research and education on a broad array of topics, which include the effects of climate change and human land use on terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems, controls on greenhouse gas release from soils and sediments, studies on the evolution of photosynthesis, studies on the microbiome of plants and animals, and investigations into the metabolic capabilities of microbial communities and microbes living in extreme environments.  The facility will be used by faculty, visiting scientists and students. 
 
The project will install two new Conviron growth chambers equipped with state of the art temperature, CO2, humidity, and lighting systems to replace older systems. The two new chambers will also be equipped with a new control system allowing for remote monitoring of the chambers and experiments. The room housing the new growth chambers will be greatly improved by moving three compressors outside, reducing the noise in the room. For studies of environmental controls over microbial activities the project will also include the installation of a Coy anaerobic chamber enabling preparation of anaerobic microbial cultures and experiments requiring strict anaerobic conditions.  This chamber will   enable new capacity for diverse work with anaerobic microbes year-round at the MBL. The room housing the new growth chambers will be greatly improved by moving three compressors (those for the two new chambers, and one for an existing chamber) outside, greatly reducing the noise in the room.  MBL’s growth chambers have been heavily used for education at all levels, from high school to Ph.D. level work and students will continue to have access to the new facilities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project provided funds for new controlled environment facilities at the Marine Biological Laboratory (MBL).  These facilities provided new capabilities which are allowing scientists to expand research on plant and soil processes, as well as on microbial interactions with plants and animals.  Two new Conviron growth chambers equipped with state-of-the-art temperature, CO2, humidity, and lighting systems were installed to replace older systems. Parts from the systems which were removed were used to repair existing systems.  The two new chambers are equipped with a new control system allowing for remote monitoring of the chambers and experiments. The room housing the new growth chambers was greatly improved by moving three compressors outside, reducing the noise in the room.  As a result researchers no longer are required to wear hearing protection within the room.

            As an example of the type of work being done, the new Conviron chamber is allowing us to conduct novel work on the saltmarsh cordgrass Sporobolus alterniflorus.  This grass is dominant in intertidal zones of salt marshes on the East and Gulf Coasts of the U.S., and is invasive on the U.S. West Coast and in Asia.  We have developed a system for generating and propagating ?axenic? plants, i.e. plants without associated microbes (Fig 1).  The procedure was greatly aided by the stringent environmental control offered by the new chambers. This will allow us to exploring interactions between plant roots and microbes controlling sulfur cycling in the ?rhizosphere?, the zone of soil surrounding a plant root where the biology and chemistry of the soil are influenced by both the roots and associated microbes.  There is evidence that this association helps allow Sporobolus survive in salt marsh sediments and we are investigating how this association becomes established. 

For studies such as the one described above, it is also necessary to be able to culture microbes which will not grow in the presence of oxygen.  Therefore, the project included the installation of a Coy anaerobic chamber. This enables the preparation of anaerobic microbial cultures and experiments requiring strict anaerobic conditions (Fig 2).  This chamber will be used to support research and education on a broad array of topics, which include the effects of climate change and human land use on terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems, controls on greenhouse gas release from soils and sediments, studies on the evolution of photosynthesis, studies on the microbiome of plants and animals, and investigations into the metabolic capabilities of microbial communities and microbes living in extreme environments.

Both the growth chambers and the anaerobic chamber will be used by faculty, visiting scientists and students.
